importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The year when the Paris Climate Agreement was reached, marking a pivotal moment in global climate policy and setting a new trajectory for greenhouse gas emissions.
The baseline period used to define 'comparable days' for climate analysis (1991–2020), providing context for the definition of superhot days.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The long-term climate projection period during which the study estimates the accumulation of 57 additional superhot days annually due to climate change.
The timeframe during which the world has already added 11 extra superhot days on average since 2015.

keyTakeAways: Climate change is increasing the number of dangerous 'superhot days' globally, defined as days warmer than 90% of comparable days from 1991 to 2020.
The world is now on track for 2.6°C (4.7°F) of warming by 2100, which still adds 57 superhot days annually — nearly two months of extreme heat.
This is half the increase from the worst-case scenario of 4°C (7.2°F) warming, which would have added 114 superhot days per year.
Since 2015, the world has already experienced an average of 11 additional superhot days.
Small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa face the largest increases in superhot days, despite contributing only 1% of global carbon emissions.
The top carbon-emitting countries — the U.S., China, and India — are projected to gain only 23–30 extra superhot days, despite responsible for 42% of global CO₂ emissions.
This climate heat inequality exacerbates global injustice and may contribute to geopolitical instability.
The study highlights the disproportionate climate impacts, showing that climate change affects the vulnerable most, regardless of emissions responsibility.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This entity conducted the study that calculates the increase in superhot days due to climate change, providing scientific attribution of extreme heat events to global warming.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The study shows that the Paris Agreement has altered the trajectory of warming from 4°C to 2.6°C, reducing the projected number of superhot days from 114 to 57.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A new study by World Weather Attribution and Climate Central finds that even under current climate commitments, the world will still see 57 additional superhot days annually by 2100 — nearly two months of extreme heat — due to climate change. This represents a significant decline from the 114 superhot days predicted under a worst-case warming scenario of 4°C. The study highlights a stark global inequity: small, ocean-dependent nations like Panama, the Solomon Islands, and Samoa will face massive increases in dangerous heat days — up to 149 extra days per year — despite contributing only 1% of global carbon emissions. In contrast, top emitters such as the U.S., China, and India face only 23–30 extra superhot days. Experts emphasize that while the Paris Agreement has reduced the worst-case warming trajectory, the future still poses severe risks for billions, and the disproportionate burden on vulnerable nations may fuel social and geopolitical instability.
title: Climate study finds overheating world will add 57 superhot days a year
